body: Looks like culprit is ["relaxed" check](https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/blob/0cc68da04f109f66159aadc2404e232ab96bb97e/alacritty/src/input.rs#L686) for mouse [introduced to allow any modifier be pressed](https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/commit/2c37da48b580237ff48f5e841015134dd459b41d). But there is no way specify "match only when *none* of modifiers is present" (actually there is [undocumented `none`](https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/blob/0cc68da04f109f66159aadc2404e232ab96bb97e/alacritty/src/config/bindings.rs#L1180) but it is as good as omitting `mods:`) and there is no way to say "match when *that* modifier is not present".

Yeah, the mouse modifier matching actually allows *more* modifiers to be pressed, but it does not allow less modifiers to be pressed.

This is because when mouse mode is enabled, you'll have to press shift to disable mouse mode to trigger your bindings. So if you want to middle mouse to paste selection, while mouse mode is enabled, you actually have to press <kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>üñ±Ô∏èMiddle</kbd>.

So the relaxed check for the mouse is mostly intended for consistency across all modifiers, but it probably makes sense to just special-case the shift modifier.

> This is because when mouse mode is enabled, you'll have to press shift to disable mouse mode to trigger your bindings. So if you want to middle mouse to paste selection, while mouse mode is enabled, you actually have to press <kbd>shift</kbd>+ <kbd>:computer_mouse: Middle</kbd>.

Ermm... Default bindings works fine by just pressing <kbd>:computer_mouse: Middle</kbd> both with and without <kbd>Shift</kbd>.  
And pressing <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>:computer_mouse: Middle</kbd> change nothing - still both actions triggered.

>Ermm... Default bindings works fine by just pressing computer_mouse Middle both with and without Shift.
And pressing Shift+Alt+computer_mouse Middle change nothing - still both actions triggered.

Because you're not in mouse mode, `Shift` is used to bypass mouse mode. You can trigger it with `echo -e "\e[?1002h"`

> Because you're not in mouse mode, `Shift` is used to by pass mouse mode. You can trigger it with `echo -e "\e[?1002h"`

Ok. Now I understand that "mouse mode" is when mouse events are passed to application. And indeed I remember use of <kbd>Shift</kbd> in RxVT to bypass it.  
Thank you. Now I understand @chrisduerr more.

Maybe making bindings for mouse reporting mode similar as for `AppCursor` and `AppKeypad`, but for `AppMouse`...
Or stripping bypass modifier (<kbd>Shift</kbd>) when resolving bindings...

I've got a patch lined up already, though I still need to decide about the exact behavior.

I feel like the best choice might just be to leave everything up to the user and execute all bindings only when the modifiers match 100%. Then the user can just check for the mode with the `mode` field and have different bindings for mouse and non-mouse mode.

That should also allow us to setup our default bindings to only trigger in mouse-mode when shift is held.

> That should also allow us to setup our default bindings to only trigger in mouse-mode when shift is held.

Problem is compatibility of settings for those who already have Alacritty installed. That's why I still think to "faking" modifiers when bypassing mouse mode is more appropriate. Though it disables firing actions that require <kbd>Shift</kbd>. But again it is matter of compatibility

```yaml
mouse_bindings:
  # right now fires in mouse mode, but will stop
  - { mouse: Middle, mods: Alt|Shift, action: PasteSelection }

  # right now doesn't fire in mouse mode, but will start
  - { mouse: Middle, mods: Alt, action: Paste }
```

issue.title: Force exact modifiers match for mouse bindings

body: @ony The previous comment with `~mouse~` is a bit outdated, since we've changed the handling a bit during some discussion on IRC. In the current state of #3153 you should be able to use your original bindings in normal mode, and to use them in mouse mode you should just press `Shift`.
